question_text: What is one of the most common causes of death worldwide, according to the presentation?

options.rationale: Coronary Artery Disease is stated as one of the most common causes of death worldwide[cite: 99].

question_text: Coronary Artery Disease is almost always caused by atherosclerosis of which artery?

options.rationale: Coronary Artery Disease is almost always caused by atherosclerosis of the coronary artery[cite: 100].

question_text: Angina is described as pain or discomfort in which area of the body?

options.rationale: Angina is described as pain/discomfort in the middle of the chest[cite: 104].

question_text: Which of the following is NOT listed as a common sign or symptom of Coronary Artery Disease?

options.rationale: Excessive thirst is not listed as a symptom of Coronary Artery Disease. [cite_start]Breathlessness, sweating, and nausea are listed[cite: 105, 106, 109].

question_text: Pain radiating from the chest in Angina can spread to which of these areas?

options.text: Neck, jaw, left arm, both arms, upper back or shoulders
options.rationale: Radiating pain from Angina can go to the neck, jaw, left arm, both arms, upper back or shoulders[cite: 108].

question_text: Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) encompasses a spectrum of conditions. Which condition is NOT explicitly listed as part of this spectrum?

options.rationale: Acute Coronary Syndrome encompasses STEMI, NSTEMI, and unstable angina, but not stable angina[cite: 119].

question_text: The risk of Ventricular Fibrillation (VF) is high in the early stages of Acute Coronary Syndrome.

options.rationale: The presentation states that the risk of VF is high in early stages of Acute Coronary Syndrome[cite: 120].

question_text: Which of the following is a common sign or symptom of Acute Coronary Syndrome?

options.text: Blurred vision in one eye only

options.rationale: Shortness of breath is listed as a sign/symptom of Acute Coronary Syndrome[cite: 128].

options.text: Sudden onset severe headache without pain

question_text: In the management of Acute Coronary Syndrome, what initial assessment should be performed?

options.text: A full set of observations and 12 lead ECG
options.rationale: Initial management for ACS includes a full set of observations and a 12 lead ECG[cite: 133].

question_text: Which of these is considered a 'red flag' in Acute Coronary Syndrome management?

options.rationale: Worsening angina is listed as a red flag for ACS[cite: 136].

question_text: If a patient's pain remains after two doses of prescribed Glyceryl Trinitrate (GTN) taken 5 minutes apart, what are they instructed to do?

options.text: Take a third dose of GTN immediately
Rest for 30 minutes before deciding on next steps

options.rationale: If pain remains after 5 minutes and a second dose of GTN, patients are instructed to call an ambulance[cite: 188].

options.text: Visit their GP the next day

question_text: What type of angina involves similar symptoms to stable angina but with no obvious pattern of triggers and takes far longer to recover?

options.rationale: Unstable angina is described as having similar symptoms to stable angina but with no obvious pattern of triggers and recovering that takes far longer[cite: 155].

question_text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Angina?

options.rationale: Tobacco use is listed as a risk factor for Angina[cite: 160].

question_text: Stable Angina chest pain is often described as a feeling of:

options.rationale: People often describe stable angina pain as a feeling of squeezing or pressure in the chest[cite: 173].

options.text: A dull ache in the fingers

question_text: Stable angina chest pain is usually triggered by physical exertion or stress and stops with rest.

options.rationale: Stable angina is triggered by physical exertion or stress and usually stops with rest[cite: 176, 177].

question_text: What type of condition is Heart Failure described as, rather than a specific disease entity?

options.rationale: Heart failure is described as a clinical disease syndrome, not a specific disease entity[cite: 199, 200].

question_text: When a patient with chronic heart failure develops worsening symptoms quickly, what is this referred to as?

options.rationale: Worsening symptoms quickly in chronic heart failure is called acute on chronic heart failure (decompensated)[cite: 202].

question_text: Which of the following is listed as a common risk factor for Heart Failure?

options.rationale: Diabetes is listed as a risk factor for Heart Failure[cite: 208].

question_text: A persistent cough, especially worse at night, is a symptom of which condition?

options.rationale: A persistent cough, which may be worse at night, is a sign of Heart Failure[cite: 215].

question_text: Heart failure can be difficult to diagnose due to the absence of condition-specific symptoms.

options.rationale: Heart failure can be difficult to diagnose due to absence of condition-specific symptoms[cite: 224].

question_text: Acute Heart Failure can present in three forms. Which of the following is NOT listed as one of these forms?

options.text: Predominant peripheral oedema with or without pulmonary oedema

options.rationale: Acute Heart Failure can present as acute pulmonary oedema, predominant peripheral oedema, or cardiogenic shock. [cite_start]TIA is not listed[cite: 228, 229, 230].

question_text: Acute Heart Failure is a life-threatening condition and all patients, unless with a specific care plan or on palliative care, should be managed as being TIME CRITICAL.

options.rationale: Acute Heart Failure is a life-threatening condition and all patients unless with a specific care plan or on palliative care should be managed as being TIME CRITICAL[cite: 231].

question_text: In the management of Acute Heart Failure, what is the blood pressure threshold for considering GTN administration?

options.rationale: GTN can be considered in Acute Heart Failure if BP >110mmHg[cite: 238].

question_text: What is an Aortic Dissection?

options.text: A clot in the brain artery
A tear in the inner layer of the body's main artery (aorta)
options.rationale: An aortic dissection is a serious condition in which a tear occurs in the inner layer of the body's main artery (aorta)[cite: 248].

options.text: A sudden inflammation of the heart muscle
A common type of heart attack

question_text: Aortic dissection is the same as an aneurysm.

options.rationale: The presentation explicitly states: 'This is not the same as an aneurysm' regarding Aortic Dissection[cite: 251].

question_text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Aortic Dissection?

options.rationale: Cocaine use is listed as a risk factor for Aortic Dissection[cite: 264].

question_text: A sudden severe chest or upper back pain, often described as a tearing or ripping sensation, is a sign of which condition?

options.rationale: Sudden severe chest or upper back pain, often described as a tearing or ripping sensation, is a sign of Aortic Dissection[cite: 36].

question_text: Sickle cell anaemia is described as the most serious type of what?

options.rationale: Sickle cell anaemia is the most serious type of sickle cell disease[cite: 37].

question_text: Sickle cell disease is a group of inherited disorders affecting the haemoglobin.

options.rationale: Sickle cell disease is described as a group of inherited disorders affecting the haemoglobin[cite: 37, 38].

question_text: Which of the following populations is NOT explicitly mentioned as being at risk for Sickle Cell Anaemia based on descent?

options.text: People of African descent, including African-Americans
Hispanic-Americans from Central and South America

options.rationale: People of Eastern European descent are not mentioned. [cite_start]African, Hispanic (Central/South America), Middle Eastern, Asian, and Indian/Mediterranean descent are listed[cite: 38, 39].

options.text: People of Middle Eastern, Asian, Indian, and Mediterranean descent

question_text: What is described as the leading cause of death and a common, life-threatening complication of a painful crisis in Sickle Cell Anaemia?

options.rationale: Acute chest syndrome is the leading cause of death, common and life-threatening complication of a painful crisis[cite: 41].

question_text: In the management of Sickle Cell Anaemia, if chest pain is present, what should be part of the initial assessment?

options.text: Full set of observations and 12 lead ECG
options.rationale: Full set of observations and 12 lead ECG if chest pain present are part of the management for Sickle Cell Anaemia[cite: 42].

question_text: The initial patient assessment should allow determination of which categories, according to the 'CUPS' mnemonic?

options.rationale: The CUPS mnemonic refers to Critical, Unstable, Potentially Unstable, and Stable patient categories[cite: 43].

question_text: If a patient is CRITICAL, UNSTABLE, or POTENTIALLY UNSTABLE, packaging the patient should begin during the rapid assessment while treating life threats.

options.rationale: If the patient is CRITICAL, UNSTABLE or POTENTIALLY UNSTABLE, begin packaging the patient during the rapid assessment while treating life threats and transport as soon as possible[cite: 43].

question_text: When prioritising assessment, a 12 lead ECG should be obtained within how many minutes?

options.rationale: A 12 lead ECG should be prioritised within 10 minutes[cite: 44].

question_text: Which mnemonics are mentioned for gathering information about the chief complaint and history of present illness during a focused history and physical exam?

options.rationale: The mnemonics OPQRST/SOCRATES and SAMPLE are used to gather information during assessment[cite: 46].

question_text: A full respiratory assessment should be carried out for any suspected cardiac patient.

options.rationale: A full respiratory assessment should be carried out for any suspected cardiac patient[cite: 47].

question_text: Which of the following is NOT explicitly mentioned as part of a respiratory assessment?

options.rationale: Respiratory assessment includes rate, rhythm, and volume. [cite_start]Temperature is not listed here[cite: 48].

question_text: A cardiac issue should be considered in any patient with a change in breathing/low SpO2 with clear lung sounds.

options.rationale: A cardiac issue should be considered in any patient with a change in breathing/low SpO2 with clear lung sounds[cite: 48].

question_text: What aspects are discussed as part of history taking in a cardiac assessment?

options.text: Hobbies, travel history, and pet ownership
Signs and symptoms, family history, social history, and medications
options.rationale: History taking for cardiac assessment includes signs and symptoms, family history, social history, and medications[cite: 49].

options.text: Favorite foods, recent movies, and shoe size
Birth weight, school attended, and first job

question_text: Which component of the diploma does this presentation support the understanding of?

options.text: Component 15: Patient Assessment Examination and Physiological Measurements
Component 19: Management of medical and surgical conditions and emergencies
options.rationale: This presentation supports understanding of component 19: Management of medical and surgical conditions and emergencies[cite: 65].

question_text: As an AAP, you must understand your own restrictions regarding the administration of medications.

options.rationale: AAP knowledge includes understanding their own restrictions of the administration of medications in accordance with the AAP’s scope of practice[cite: 68].

question_text: What is the pass mark for the Exam (C19 – Management of Medical and Surgical Conditions and Emergencies)?

options.rationale: The pass mark for the exam is 80%[cite: 95].

question_text: Coronary Artery Disease is most commonly caused by what?

options.rationale: Coronary Artery Disease is almost always caused by atherosclerosis of the coronary artery[cite: 100].

question_text: Which symptom is described as a 'similar feeling to indigestion' in the context of Coronary Artery Disease?

options.text: Pain in your lower chest or belly
options.rationale: Pain in your lower chest or belly can be similar to indigestion[cite: 181]. [cite_start]This symptom is related to angina which is covered under CAD[cite: 178, 181].

question_text: The chest pain in Acute Coronary Syndrome may involve pressure, tightness, or fullness.

options.rationale: Chest pain or discomfort in ACS may involve pressure, tightness or fullness[cite: 126].

question_text: Which drug, when considered in ACS management, is a P2Y12 inhibitor?

options.rationale: Ticagrelor is listed as a drug to consider in ACS management[cite: 146]. (Note: While the slide doesn't explicitly state it's a P2Y12 inhibitor, it is a known medication in ACS management and helps create a plausible distractor.)

question_text: What is the acronym suggested for describing ACS pain characteristics?

options.rationale: The acronym SOCRATES is suggested for ACS pain characteristics[cite: 150].

question_text: Which of these is NOT a listed risk factor for Angina?

options.rationale: Not enough exercise is a risk factor, implying regular physical activity would *not* be a risk factor[cite: 165].

question_text: In the management of angina, if in doubt, it is usually safest to manage the patient as if they are suffering from ACS.

options.rationale: If in doubt, angina patients should be treated as ACS[cite: 185, 189].

question_text: What is a major risk factor for Heart Failure, also described as the most common type of heart disease?

options.rationale: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease and a risk factor for heart failure[cite: 207].

question_text: Which of these is a listed sign or symptom of Heart Failure?

options.rationale: A bloated tummy is a sign/symptom of Heart Failure[cite: 217].

question_text: Furosemide is a medication considered for Acute Heart Failure management and is administered by Paramedics.

options.rationale: Furosemide (Paramedic) is a consideration in Acute Heart Failure management[cite: 239].

question_text: If the blood goes through the outside aortic wall in an aortic dissection, what is the consequence?

options.text: It leads to a minor bruise.
It often results in complete recovery.

options.rationale: If the blood goes through the outside aortic wall, aortic dissection is often deadly[cite: 250].

question_text: Which of these is NOT a listed risk factor for Aortic Dissection?

options.rationale: Regular aerobic exercise is not a risk factor for Aortic Dissection. [cite_start]Hardening of arteries and high blood pressure are[cite: 254, 255].

question_text: What type of inherited disorder is Sickle Cell Disease?

options.text: A group of inherited disorders affecting haemoglobin
options.rationale: Sickle cell disease is a group of inherited disorder affecting the haemoglobin[cite: 37, 38].

question_text: Which of these is a listed sign or symptom of Sickle Cell Anaemia?

options.rationale: Severe headache is a sign/symptom of Sickle Cell Anaemia[cite: 39].

question_text: Patients with Sickle Cell Anaemia are at high risk of thrombus and Pulmonary Embolism (PE).

options.rationale: Patients are at high risk of thrombus and PE[cite: 42].

question_text: Stroke should be suspected in any patient with reduced consciousness, seizure, severe headache, or what other type of symptoms in Sickle Cell Anaemia?

options.rationale: Stroke should be suspected in any patient with reduced consciousness/seizure/severe headache or FAST symptoms[cite: 42].

question_text: In the focused assessment phase, what is used to gather information about the chief complaint and history of the present illness?

options.rationale: During this phase of the patient assessment, the mnemonic OPQRST/ SOCRATES and SAMPLE will be used to gather information about the chief complaint and history of the present illness[cite: 46].

question_text: What is the primary cause mentioned for many cardiovascular conditions covered in the session?

options.rationale: Many cardiovascular conditions that we are going to cover in this session are most commonly caused by Coronary Artery Disease[cite: 98].

question_text: Fatigue is a listed symptom of Coronary Artery Disease.

options.rationale: Fatigue is listed as a symptom of Coronary Artery Disease[cite: 110].

question_text: Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) includes which of the following?

options.rationale: ACS encompasses STEMI, NSTEMI, and unstable angina[cite: 119].

question_text: What type of pain is characteristic of Stable Angina that does NOT change with respiration, body position, or tenderness?

options.text: Fixed Pattern of exertional Chest pain
options.rationale: Chronic Stable Angina is characterized by Fixed Pattern of exertional Chest pain that does NOT change with respiration, body position, or tenderness[cite: 153].

options.text: Radiating pain to the right leg

question_text: Emotional stress is a listed risk factor for Angina.

options.rationale: Emotional stress is a listed risk factor for Angina[cite: 167].

question_text: What is the most common symptom of stable angina?

options.rationale: Chest pain is the most common symptom of stable angina[cite: 172].

question_text: In the management of angina, what initial assessment should be performed?

options.text: Full set of observations and ECG
options.rationale: Initial management for Angina includes a full set of observations and ECG[cite: 184].

question_text: Many people live in the community with what form of heart failure?

options.rationale: Many people live in the community with chronic heart failure (CHF/ Congestive heart failure)[cite: 201].

question_text: Which of the following is a symptom of Heart Failure that relates to fluid retention?

options.rationale: Oedema is listed as a sign/symptom of Heart Failure[cite: 31, 223].

question_text: What posture is recommended for patients in Acute Heart Failure?

options.rationale: Sit patient upright is a management step for Acute Heart Failure[cite: 236].

question_text: An aortic dissection involves blood rushing through a tear, causing which layers of the aorta to split?

options.rationale: Blood rushes through the tear, causing the inner and middle layers of the aorta to split (dissect)[cite: 249].

question_text: Which genetic condition, involving connective tissue disorders, is a risk factor for Aortic Dissection?

options.rationale: Marfan syndrome is listed as a risk factor for Aortic Dissection[cite: 260].

question_text: What type of pain is most commonly experienced in Sickle Cell Anaemia crisis?

options.text: Sever pain most commonly in long bones and/or joints of arms or legs but also back, chest and abdomen
options.rationale: Sever pain most commonly in long bones and/or joints of arms or legs but also back, chest and abdomen is a sign of Sickle Cell Anaemia[cite: 39].

question_text: Patients experiencing a sickle cell crisis are often very informed about their usual management.

options.rationale: Patients are often very informed about their usual management in a sickle cell crisis[cite: 40].

question_text: What assessment category implies that packaging the patient and immediate transport should begin during rapid assessment?

options.rationale: If the patient is CRITICAL, UNSTABLE or POTENTIALLY UNSTABLE, begin packaging the patient during the rapid assessment while treating life threats and transport as soon as possible[cite: 43].

question_text: What vital sign assessment should be prioritized within 10 minutes according to the presentation?

options.rationale: Prioritise a 12 lead ECG within 10 minutes[cite: 44].

question_text: Which condition is characterized by pain/discomfort in the middle of the chest, breathlessness, sweating, and nausea?

options.rationale: These are listed symptoms of Angina[cite: 104, 105, 106, 109].

question_text: Which three conditions are specifically mentioned as falling under the category of Acute Coronary Syndrome?

options.rationale: Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) encompasses STEMI, NSTEMI, and unstable angina[cite: 119].

options.text: Aortic Aneurysm, Aortic Stenosis, Aortic Regurgitation

question_text: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a listed risk factor for Angina.

options.rationale: CKD is listed as a risk factor for Angina[cite: 164].

question_text: Which of these is NOT a characteristic of Chronic Stable Angina's fixed pattern of exertional chest pain?

options.rationale: Chronic Stable Angina pain does NOT change with respiration (pleuritic), NOT change with body position, NO tenderness[cite: 153].

options.text: Relieved by rest or sub-lingual nitrates

question_text: According to NICE (2011), how long should a patient wait after taking a dose of GTN before taking a second dose and, if pain persists, calling an ambulance?

options.rationale: Take a dose of GTN, wait 5 minutes and take a second dose. [cite_start]If their pain remains after 5 minutes they are instructed to call an ambulance (NICE, 2011)[cite: 187, 188].

question_text: Which of these is a listed risk factor for Heart Failure that is 'other Conditions Related to Heart Disease'?

options.rationale: Valvular Heart Disease is listed under 'Other Conditions Related to Heart Disease' as a risk factor for Heart Failure[cite: 211, 212].

question_text: A fast heart rate is a listed sign or symptom of Heart Failure.

options.rationale: A fast heart rate is a sign/symptom of Heart Failure[cite: 222].

question_text: What type of shock can Acute Heart Failure present as?

options.rationale: Acute Heart Failure can present as cardiogenic shock[cite: 230].

question_text: Which risk factor for Aortic Dissection is related to a narrowing of the aorta at birth?

options.rationale: A narrowing of the aorta at birth (aortic coarctation) is a risk factor for Aortic Dissection[cite: 258].

question_text: Which gender and age group are mentioned as risk factors for Aortic Dissection?

options.rationale: Male and 60+ are listed as risk factors for Aortic Dissection[cite: 262, 263].

question_text: Which of these is a sign or symptom of Aortic Dissection that mimics a stroke?

options.rationale: Symptoms similar to those of a stroke, including sudden vision problems, are a sign of Aortic Dissection[cite: 37].

options.text: Pins and needles in the face

question_text: Sickle cell crisis, also known as vaso-occlusive crisis, occurs when the blockage causes what?

options.rationale: This means the blockage is causing tissue ischaemia in a sickle cell crisis[cite: 40].

question_text: Which of the following is a management step for Sickle Cell Anaemia crisis?

options.text: Immediate blood transfusion for all patients

options.rationale: Pain relief and oxygen are management steps for Sickle Cell Anaemia crisis[cite: 42].

question_text: When managing service users, particularly the elderly, in an emergency and urgent care setting, what management aspect is highlighted as a skill for an AAP?

options.text: Focusing only on the primary injury

options.rationale: Skills for an AAP include: airway, respiratory & circulatory management[cite: 72].

options.text: Delegating all care to a higher authority immediately
